study_goal: The researchers aimed to retrospectively assess the age at which early motor milestones, including walking, were achieved in boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD).
results_summary: The study found that walking was achieved at a mean age of 16.35 months in DMD boys, with 17% not achieving independent walking by 18 months. The delay in walking was more pronounced in boys with mutations beyond exon 63 (42% not walking by 18 months).
population_specificity: Boys with Duchenne muscular dystrophy (n=134).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a multilevel physical activity intervention could increase walking in larger life-space domains among older adults.
results_summary: The intervention increased walking time in Campus, Neighborhood, and Beyond Neighborhood domains, with effects observed across genders and physical/cognitive functioning groups. The study demonstrated that individual, social, and environmental support for walking can enhance physical activity in older adults.
population_specificity: 305 community-dwelling older adults (mean age 83, 73% women) living in retirement communities.

study_goal: To investigate the effectiveness of conservative nonpharmacologic therapies, including directed exercise and manual therapy, on pain, disability, physical capacity, and physical activity outcomes in patients with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).
results_summary: Directed exercise and manual therapy improved short-term walking capacity, back pain, leg pain, and symptom severity compared to self-directed or group exercise, with low- to moderate-quality evidence. Rehabilitation was not clearly better than surgery for intermediate- or long-term disability, based on very low-quality evidence.
population_specificity: Adults with degenerative lumbar spinal stenosis (LSS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of dementia on postoperative walking ability and other complications following hip fracture surgery.
results_summary: The study found that dementia significantly negatively affects postoperative walking ability recovery, increases complications (infection, hip dislocation, delirium, respiratory issues), and raises mortality rates at different periods.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with dementia who underwent hip fracture surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of pure curcumin on rheumatoid arthritis (RA), including its effects on walking time as one of the clinical parameters.
results_summary: The study found that curcumin improved walking time, morning stiffness, and joint swelling in RA patients, with most studies supporting its anti-inflammatory effects through various mechanisms.
population_specificity: RA patients (one human study included)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether preoperative physiotherapy (pulmonary prehabilitation) improves outcomes for patients undergoing lung resection, including reducing postoperative complications and enhancing exercise capacity.
results_summary: The study found that preoperative rehabilitation programs significantly reduced postoperative pulmonary complications, decreased hospital length of stay, and improved exercise capacity (measured by 6-minute walking distance and peak oxygen uptake). Multiple meta-analyses and trials supported these benefits.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing surgical resection for lung cancer, particularly those borderline for surgical suitability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether patients referred for a DXA exam were informed about risk factors for osteoporosis, including the effect of walking.
results_summary: The study found that patients were poorly informed about osteoporosis risk factors, with walking being one of the less known topics. No significant differences in knowledge were found between those who knew they had osteoporosis and those who did not.
population_specificity: Patients referred for a DXA exam at the Osteoporosis Service of Marche Nord Hospital (Fano, Italy), predominantly women (95.6%) with a mean age of 66.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe a rare case of symptomatic mirror lumbar spinal dural arteriovenous fistula (SDAVF) and its impact on walking ability, highlighting diagnostic challenges and treatment outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that a mirror lumbar SDAVF caused progressive walking deterioration and urinary retention, which was initially missed on MRI but later identified through vascular imaging. Surgical management led to significant symptom improvement.
population_specificity: A 78-year-old male with progressive walking deterioration and urinary retention.
study_duration: Symptoms progressed over 10 months before diagnosis and treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether portable non-invasive ventilation (pNIV) during walking improves dyspnea and endurance capacity in patients with moderate to severe COPD.
results_summary: The study found that pNIV use during walking improved dyspnea and walking distance in COPD patients, with greater benefits observed in those not already receiving long-term NIV therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate to severe COPD (mean age 66.9 ± 7.4 years).
effective_dosage: Pre-set inspiratory/expiratory positive airway pressure of 18/8 cmH₂O.
study_duration: Not specified (crossover trials with standardized 6-minute walking tests).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the medium-term impact of SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia on lung function, quality of life, and functional capacity, including walking ability, in affected patients.
results_summary: The study found that 79.5% of patients reported poor health perception due to respiratory symptoms, and all patients showed decreased quality of life. Functional impairment was observed in 64.1% of patients, as assessed by lung function tests and the 6-minute walking test.
population_specificity: 39 patients with SARS-CoV-2 pneumonia from a single COVID-19 hospital in Southern Switzerland.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether preconditioning local vibration alters plantar skin blood flow after walking by analyzing metabolic and neurogenic controls.
results_summary: Preconditioning local vibration significantly increased metabolic and neurogenic control of skin blood flow after walking compared to sham conditions, but no differences were observed in myogenic, respiratory, or cardiac controls.
population_specificity: 10 healthy participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lower extremity intermittent negative pressure (INP) treatment on walking distance in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The treatment group (-40 mm Hg INP) showed significant improvement in pain-free walking distance (PWD) compared to the sham control group (-10 mm Hg INP), particularly in patients with baseline PWD <200 m. No significant differences were found in maximal walking distance (MWD), ankle-brachial index, blood flow, or quality of life between groups.
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
effective_dosage: -40 mm Hg INP for 1 hour, two times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the determinants of older adults' willingness to participate in a community-based functional training exercise program, including walking, as part of a care prevention initiative.
results_summary: More than half of participants (51.4%) were willing to join the program, with motivators including younger age, female gender, marital status, employment, exercise habits, fall history, and need for walking aids or secondary caregivers.
population_specificity: Older adults (community-dwelling seniors) in Thailand.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether BEAR-H1 assisted gait training (BAGT) improves motor and walking ability in subacute stroke patients compared to conventional training.
results_summary: BAGT showed more noticeable improvements in 6MWT, FMA-LE, gait speed, cadence, step length, and cycle duration than conventional training, but no difference in MAS scores. The study concluded BAGT is effective for enhancing motor and walking ability in subacute stroke patients.
population_specificity: Subacute stroke patients with walking disabilities.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of BAGT or conventional training, 5 times/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether five-week robotic gait training could improve propulsion symmetry and paretic propulsion in chronic stroke survivors.
results_summary: The intervention significantly improved propulsion symmetry, paretic propulsive impulse, gait speed, functional gait tasks, and daily-life walking activity levels, with gains retained at follow-up. Larger improvements were associated with greater baseline asymmetry.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke survivors with impaired paretic propulsion (≥ 8% difference in paretic vs. non-paretic propulsive impulse).
effective_dosage: Ten 60-minute sessions of robotic gait training (twice a week) plus 15-minute daily home exercises.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes and behavioral changes between self-monitored and supervised walking interventions for older adults.
results_summary: Both self-monitored and supervised walking improved most physical functions, particularly lower-extremity performance, with no significant differences except for BMI and cardiopulmonary endurance. The supervised group showed improvements in BMI, muscle strength, and balance, while the self-monitored group improved in knee extension muscle strength and mobility.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptance, and short-term effects of immersive VR-based treadmill training compared to semi-immersive and conventional treadmill training on walking speed and motivation in healthy participants and patients with MS or stroke.
results_summary: Walking speed was higher in the immersive VR (HMD) condition compared to the semi-immersive (monitor) and conventional treadmill training. Healthy participants reported higher motivation with the HMD condition, and usability ratings were high with no simulator sickness or increased heart rate observed. Most participants preferred the HMD-based training.
population_specificity: 36 healthy participants and 14 persons with MS or stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery (VATS) and traditional thoracotomy on patient-reported outcomes, including walking ability, in locally advanced lung cancer patients.
results_summary: VATS patients reported significantly better walking ability (p < 0.0001) during postoperative hospitalization compared to thoracotomy patients. Post-discharge, VATS patients also showed better overall quality of life and functional outcomes.
population_specificity: 117 primary lung cancer patients (stage II or III).
study_duration: Data collected preoperatively, daily postoperatively during hospitalization, and weekly up to 4 weeks post-discharge or until adjuvant therapy began.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify differences in gait recovery patterns based on the paralyzed side of post-stroke patients to contribute to personalized rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pelvic movement symmetries and reductions in center of pressure (COP) area and velocity in both left and right hemiparesis groups, with gait recovery patterns differing by the paralyzed side. Lateral symmetry also improved, though not statistically significant, as walking ability increased in both groups.
population_specificity: Right-handed post-stroke patients who could walk independently, divided into right (n=19) and left (n=20) hemiparesis groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether text message reminders could enhance postoperative ambulation as part of the I COUGH protocol.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a 9-fold increase in daily walks (1.8 ± 1.8 walks per day) compared to the control group (0.2 ± 1.0 walks per day), with statistically significant improvement (p = 0.03). Text message reminders effectively increased adherence to postoperative walking.
population_specificity: Inpatients in a safety-net, academic medical center undergoing postoperative care.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved text message reminders).
study_duration: Not specified (duration of postoperative follow-up not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify changes in hip geometry and gait pattern after total hip arthroplasty (THA) and explore how postoperative changes in femoral neck anteversion and femoral/acetabular offset affect hip rotation and adduction moment during walking.
results_summary: One year post-THA, gait quality improved with faster walking speed, reduced trunk lean, and symmetrical global offset. Changes in hip rotation during walking were associated with changes in femoral neck anteversion, while increased external hip adduction moments correlated with upright walking and higher speed, not femoral/acetabular offset changes.
population_specificity: 65 individuals with primary hip osteoarthritis scheduled for THA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robotic exoskeleton-assisted exercise rehabilitation (REAER) versus conventional gait training (CGT) on functional mobility, walking endurance, cognitive processing speed, and brain connectivity in persons with substantial MS-related neurological disability.
results_summary: REAER showed large improvements in functional mobility and cognitive processing speed compared to CGT, potentially due to increased thalamocortical resting-state functional connectivity. The study suggests REAER may be more effective than traditional gait training for improving mobility and cognition in severely disabled MS patients.
population_specificity: 10 persons with substantial MS-related neurological disability

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of exercise training alone versus exercise training combined with kinesio taping on pain, functionality, and biomarkers in knee osteoarthritis patients.
results_summary: Both exercise training and exercise training plus kinesio taping improved pain and physical function, but no significant changes were observed in COMP, MMP-1, or MMP-3 levels.
population_specificity: 22 female patients diagnosed with knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of walking exercise before and after interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of motivational interviewing (MI) on enhancing self-care behaviors, including adherence to treatment and symptom monitoring, in patients with heart failure (HF).
results_summary: MI showed moderate to large effects on improving self-care confidence, management, and maintenance in HF patients, but no significant effects on physical functioning, including the 6-minute walking test.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (HF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 24 weeks of land walking or water walking induces adaptation in cerebrovascular function in older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in resting intracranial blood flow velocities or neurovascular coupling after either walking intervention. However, water walking showed a modest improvement in autoregulatory normalized gain, and pooled exercise data indicated a correlation between increased fitness and decreased hypercapnic reactivity.
population_specificity: 63 older adults (62 ± 7 years, 46 females)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of cilostazol, home exercise therapy, supervised exercise therapy (SET), endovascular revascularization (ER), and ER plus SET in improving maximum walking distance (MWD) in people with intermittent claudication over short-, moderate-, and long-term follow-up.
results_summary: SET and ER+SET significantly improved MWD over short- and moderate-term follow-up, but no treatments showed significant improvement in the long term. Adverse events and quality of life were inconsistently reported and could not be meta-analyzed.
population_specificity: People with intermittent claudication (4,256 patients across 46 trials).
study_duration: Short-term (<1 year), moderate-term (1 to <2 years), and long-term (≥2 years) follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the etiology, clinical manifestations, diagnosis, and treatment of pelvic obliquity in cerebral palsy patients with neuromuscular scoliosis, focusing on its impact on walking difficulties.
results_summary: The study found that pelvic obliquity exacerbates walking difficulties in cerebral palsy patients with neuromuscular scoliosis, and interventions like posterior fusion, contracture release, and osteotomy can restore proper alignment and improve walking.
population_specificity: Cerebral palsy patients with neuromuscular scoliosis and pelvic obliquity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review neurotechnological approaches for restoring natural sensory feedback in prosthetic devices for amputees to improve walking and movement control.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the unmet clinical need for sensory feedback in prosthetics, discusses the challenges of unphysiological walking and force control, and reviews potential solutions to restore natural sensations.
population_specificity: Arm and leg amputees.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively evaluate the immediate effects of Nabiximols on walking and balance in people with Multiple Sclerosis (pwMS) and spasticity, and assess the persistence of these effects after 4 weeks.
results_summary: The study found significant short-term improvements in walking and balance in the Sativex group compared to controls, with the best efficacy observed in patients identified as responders by both NRSs and BBS. These improvements persisted after 4 weeks.
population_specificity: People with Multiple Sclerosis (pwMS) and spasticity (32 participants: 22 in the Sativex group, 10 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the multivariable correlates of work capacity, including factors like anemia, physical activity, and sociodemographic characteristics, in non-pregnant women in rural India.
results_summary: The study found that approximately 61% of participants had anemia, but factors other than anemia were also important correlates of work capacity. The results suggest that broader health and behavioral factors should be considered when promoting the health and economic capacity of rural Indian women.
population_specificity: Non-pregnant women (15-49 years) living in rural Odisha, India.
study_duration: Data collection occurred between 2018 and 2021, with activity monitoring for 3 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association between patient characteristics (including impaired walking) identified in a multidimensional nursing assessment and outcomes of mortality and acute hospitalization during community hospital stay.
results_summary: Impaired walking was associated with an increased risk of acute hospitalization (OR 2.50, 95% CI 1.03-6.06). No direct safety or efficacy outcomes related to walking as an intervention were reported.
population_specificity: Patients admitted to a community hospital in Loreto, Italy (mean age 83 ± 9.9 years, 60.4% female).
study_duration: Mean length of stay was 42.8 ± 36 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether virtual reality (VR) walking trails could improve patient knowledge retention, satisfaction, and attendance in cardiac rehabilitation (CR) compared to standard therapy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between the VR intervention group and the control group in 6-minute walk test improvement, cardiac knowledge, or satisfaction. However, the control group had statistically better attendance rates.
population_specificity: New cardiac rehabilitation patients (72 participants, 41 in the intervention group and 31 in the control group).
study_duration: From January 2018 to May 2019 (exact intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of enzyme replacement therapy (ERT) in improving walking distance, respiratory function, and muscle strength in patients with late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant improvement in walking distance (32.2 m greater during the observed period, p=0.0003) but no significant improvement in respiratory function (FVC) and only a non-significant tendency toward better muscle strength with ERT.
population_specificity: Patients with late-onset Pompe disease (LOPD) (589 patients across 16 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the feasibility of a ballet-inspired at-home workout programme (FBB) for improving balance, gait, and walking endurance in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study will assess recruitment rates, adherence to FBB, and outcomes like balance, gait, and memory, comparing changes between the intervention and control groups. Qualitative data will also be analyzed to form themes and subthemes.
population_specificity: 40 adults with first-ever ischaemic or haemorrhagic stroke and mild-moderate lower limb paresis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the natural course of metachromatic leukodystrophy (MLD) and identify biomarkers to monitor disease progression, including the association of independent walking with disease milestones.
results_summary: The study found that in late-infantile MLD patients, attaining independent walking was associated with a later age at dysphagia. Late-infantile and early-juvenile patients showed rapid loss of ambulation, but late-infantile patients displayed earlier loss of trunk control and other severe milestones.
population_specificity: 22 late-infantile, 14 early-juvenile, 5 late-juvenile, and 4 adult MLD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether structured physical activity (walking) was associated with less decline in lower-extremity function among older adults with versus without metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The study found that moderate-intensity physical activity (walking) improved 400-m walking speed in older adults with MetS but not in those without MetS, while no benefit was observed on the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score in either group.
population_specificity: Sedentary, functionally-vulnerable older adults (70-89 years old) with and without metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Structured, moderate-intensity physical activity (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of modified rehabilitation programs versus standard rehabilitation programs after total knee arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found no systematic improvement in clinical outcomes from modified rehabilitation programs compared to standard approaches, with no clear pattern favoring specific modifications. Only two studies showed significant improvement, but no particular modification could be solely credited.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent total knee arthroplasty for osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a five-session physical activity prescription versus a one-hour advice session in increasing physical activity levels among patients with hip or knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Both groups showed significant improvements in self-reported physical activity, symptoms, and quality of life, but the prescription group had a greater reduction in pain after walking. No other significant differences were found between the two interventions.
population_specificity: Patients aged 40-74 with clinically verified osteoarthritis of the hip or knee who undertook less than 150 minutes/week of moderate physical activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the incidence, anatomy, and classification of paediatric femoral fractures, focusing on contemporary management techniques for different anatomical segments.
results_summary: The study highlights that femoral neck fractures require prompt reduction and fixation to prevent avascular necrosis, diaphyseal fractures have varied management options based on patient age and size, and distal femoral fractures often involve the physis, risking growth arrest and deformity. Long-term surveillance is recommended for early intervention.
population_specificity: Paediatric patients with femoral fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare gait parameters and clinical outcomes between conventional and robotic-assisted techniques for unicompartmental knee arthroplasty (UKA).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in gait parameters, clinical scores, implant position, or complication rates between robotic-assisted and conventional UKA techniques. Both groups showed improvement in varus deformity post-operatively.
population_specificity: 66 patients undergoing medial UKA (33 robotic-assisted, 33 conventional).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of a 30-minute walk compared to rest in improving quality of life and other clinical outcomes in patients with mild to moderate myasthenia gravis (MG).
results_summary: The study found that patients in the exercise arm had significantly better quality of life (MG-QOL15) and walking distance (6MWT) compared to the rest arm, with no reported adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate myasthenia gravis (MG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of robotic locomotor training (RLT) and activity-based training (ABT) on cardiovascular indices in individuals with spinal cord injury during different physiological positions.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in most cardiovascular measures between RLT and ABT groups, but RLT showed better improvement in cardiac responses to orthostatic stress and cardiovascular efficiency during walking. Both interventions had limited effects on brachial and ankle blood pressure.
population_specificity: Individuals with chronic traumatic motor incomplete tetraplegia (N=16) residing in Western Cape, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 50 Hz vs. 100 Hz local vibration (LV) on mild-moderate spasticity, functional performance, and muscle architecture in patients.
results_summary: The 50 Hz LV group showed significant improvements in spasticity, fascicle length, and walking parameters, while the 100 Hz group improved in velocity, step length, and base of support. Medio-lateral limits of stability were better in the 50 Hz group compared to others.
population_specificity: Thirty-three patients (reduced to 27) with mild-moderate spasticity.
effective_dosage: LV applied to medial gastrocnemius muscles for five minutes, three days a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the early biomechanical outcomes of patients with acetabular fractures treated using the less invasive pararectus approach, focusing on walking and stair climbing performance.
results_summary: Patients showed no differences in lower extremity kinematics during walking and stair climbing but exhibited reduced vertical ground reaction forces and hip/knee extension moments. Despite some biomechanical restrictions, mobility was preserved, and functional outcomes were acceptable.
population_specificity: Eight patients (48 ± 14 years, BMI 25.8 ± 3 kg/m²) with surgically treated acetabular fractures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ground-based walking training in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients using the endurance shuttle walk test (ESWT) and compare participant characteristics and test responsiveness based on pre-training walking speeds.
results_summary: Participants who walked at faster speeds during pre-training ESWTs showed milder dyspnea and leg fatigue at baseline and achieved greater improvements in ESWT time post-training. Repeating the ESWT at faster speeds to achieve moderate symptoms within 5-10 minutes may enhance training responsiveness.
population_specificity: COPD patients (70 ± 9 years, FEV1 43 ± 15% predicted).
effective_dosage: Supervised ground-based walking training, 2-3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors associated with changes in mobility (walking or wheelchair use) in patients with paralysis syndromes after acute inpatient rehabilitation, focusing on participation-oriented rehab interventions.
results_summary: The study plans to assess mobility data (daily distance covered) and its association with participation-oriented rehab interventions, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with mobility-restricting paralysis syndromes (stroke or spinal cord injury) in Germany.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bacterial cellulose nanofiber sheets loaded with venlafaxin and doxycycline could expedite healing and reduce neuropathy in diabetic foot ulcers.
results_summary: The treatment group showed faster reduction in ulcer size, decreased abnormal responses in neuropathy screening, and increased pain-free walking distance compared to the control group. Microscopic studies indicated reduced inflammation and formation of new capillary beds.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetic foot ulcers.

study_goal: To assess the feasibility of a multi-site randomised controlled trial evaluating the effect of functional electrical stimulation on bradykinesia in people with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found a mean difference of 0.14 m/s in walking speed between groups, suggesting feasibility and potential efficacy of the intervention. Both the study protocol and intervention were deemed acceptable, though modifications were recommended.
population_specificity: 64 participants with idiopathic Parkinson's disease and slow gait (<1.25 m/s).
effective_dosage: Not specified (functional electrical stimulation delivered to the common peroneal nerve while walking).
study_duration: 18 weeks intervention period with 4 weeks post-intervention follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effects of lower extremity intermittent negative pressure (INP) treatment after 24 weeks in patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
results_summary: The study found significant increases in pain-free walking distance (PWD) and maximal walking distance (MWD) after 24 weeks of INP treatment, with PWD improving mainly in the first 12 weeks and MWD improving between 12 and 24 weeks. No significant changes were observed in resting or post-exercise ankle-brachial index (ABI).
population_specificity: Patients with intermittent claudication (IC).
effective_dosage: -40 mm Hg INP for one hour twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess treatment fidelity (TF) of a home-based walking intervention and its association with improvements in 6-minute walk distance (∆6MWD) in post-hip fracture patients.
results_summary: The study found that higher attendance, progression in training load, endurance duration, and exercising on the floor were significantly associated with improved ∆6MWD, with floor exercises showing the strongest improvement (62 m more than non-floor exercisers).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults post-hip fracture.
effective_dosage: 16 weeks of lower extremity strengthening, function, and endurance training (specific frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of cooling on physiological responses and hyperthermia risk in firefighters wearing protective clothing during exercise in a hot environment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of cooling on physiological responses or hyperthermia probability.
population_specificity: Twelve male participants.

study_goal: To determine whether low-intensity home-based walking exercise improves walking ability in people with lower-extremity peripheral artery disease (PAD) compared to high-intensity walking exercise and a nonexercise control.
results_summary: High-intensity walking exercise significantly improved 6-minute walk distance compared to low-intensity exercise and the control group, while low-intensity exercise showed no significant difference from the control. Serious adverse events were slightly higher in the exercise groups but mostly unrelated to the study.
population_specificity: 305 participants with PAD (mean age 69.3 years, 47.9% women, 59.3% Black).
effective_dosage: 5 times per week for up to 50 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility of using nasal high-flow therapy (NHFT) during exercise in patients with cystic fibrosis (CF) and severe lung disease, and its potential to improve walking distance and respiratory outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that NHFT improved treadmill walking distance by a mean of 19 meters and was well-tolerated with no adverse events. Recruitment and data completion rates were high, supporting the feasibility of further clinical trials.
population_specificity: 23 participants with CF and severe lung disease.
effective_dosage: Not specified (NHFT was used during treadmill walking tests).
study_duration: Two treadmill walking tests conducted 24-48 hours apart.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a 12-week brisk walking and diet education program could improve quality of life, sleep, rest-activity rhythms, anxiety, and depression in esophageal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that the rehabilitation program significantly improved reflux symptoms and marginally improved emotional and social functions, constipation, eating difficulty, anxiety, and total sleep time compared to standard care.
population_specificity: Patients with esophageal cancer (n=44).
effective_dosage: Brisk walking (specific frequency/intensity not detailed) and diet education.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand motor control factors affecting inter-limb coordination in children with cerebral palsy and whether coordination could improve with intervention.
results_summary: The study found that deficits in motor control, muscle tone, and weakness contribute to poor coordination in children with cerebral palsy, and interventions like motor-learning rehabilitation or botulinum toxin injections may improve coordination. Continuous relative phase analysis was recommended for better evaluation of limb movements.
population_specificity: Children with cerebral palsy

study_goal: The study aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and benefits of autologous bone marrow-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) and c-kit positive cardiac cells (CPCs) in patients with heart failure caused by ischaemic cardiomyopathy, not Walking.
results_summary: The study did not assess Walking; it focused on cell therapies for heart failure, showing improved clinical outcomes (MACE and quality of life) with CPCs and MSCs.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure caused by ischaemic cardiomyopathy (left ventricular ejection fraction of 28.6 ± 6.1%, scar size 19.4 ± 5.8%, NYHA class II or III).
effective_dosage: Not mentioned (focused on cell injections, not Walking).
study_duration: 12 months (follow-up period for cell therapy, not Walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of exercise therapy on lower limb muscle oxygenation in patients with lower extremity artery disease (LEAD) using near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS).
results_summary: Exercise training improved de-oxygenation and re-oxygenation patterns in patients with LEAD, as measured by NIRS, but methodological heterogeneity and underreporting of NIRS data reproducibility were noted.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity artery disease (LEAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi on oxidative stress markers (OxSM) with sedentary behavior, walking, or yoga.
results_summary: Only one study compared Tai Chi to walking regarding OxSM, but the abstract does not report specific findings for walking. The study primarily found that Tai Chi increased superoxide dismutase and catalase levels while reducing lipoperoxides compared to sedentary behavior.
population_specificity: Not specified for walking (abstract focuses on Tai Chi participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the immediate and long-term effects of mHealth interventions on physical activity, with walking as one of the primary outcome measures.
results_summary: mHealth interventions significantly increased walking at the end of the intervention (SMD 0.46), with effects sustained in both short-term (≤6 months, SMD 0.26) and long-term (>6 months, SMD 0.25) follow-ups. The study found higher effect scores in sick and at-risk populations.
population_specificity: Adults with a mean age of 52.03 years (58.99% female), including sick and at-risk populations.
study_duration: Varied (end of intervention, ≤6 months, >6 months follow-ups)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two types of whole body vibrating platforms (vertical and rotational) in improving health status for fibromyalgia patients over a 12-week training program.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effectiveness of the interventions, but it implies a comparison between vertical and rotational whole body vibration platforms for fibromyalgia patients.
population_specificity: Sixty fibromyalgia patients (90% women).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the benefits of 4-week, in-home wearable focal muscle vibration (FMV) therapy on pain, balance, mobility, and sensation in people with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN).
results_summary: The study explored FMV therapy's effects on DPN symptoms, comparing different FMV intensities, but specific results regarding efficacy were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: People with diabetic peripheral neuropathy (DPN)
effective_dosage: Different FMV intensities (specific amounts not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of walking backward on a treadmill on balance, walking speed, and cardiopulmonary fitness in patients with chronic stroke.
results_summary: The study found that the experimental group, which received additional backward treadmill walking, showed improvements in functional balance, walking ability, and cardiopulmonary fitness compared to the control group. These outcomes were measured using standardized tests like the Berg Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go test, 10-Meter Walk Test, and 6-Minute Walk Test.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic stroke (more than six months post-stroke), Brunnstrom stage > IV, able to walk at least 11 meters with or without assistive devices.
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of traditional physical therapy three times a week, plus an additional 30 minutes of backward treadmill walking for the experimental group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of Nordic walking on functional and postural changes of the trunk in women of different ages after breast cancer, hypothesizing an age-related relationship.
results_summary: Nordic walking improved psychophysical condition in breast cancer survivors and was studied for its effects on functional and postural trunk changes. The abstract suggests a potential age-related impact but does not detail specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors (women of different ages)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a novel oral nutritional supplement improved walking performance in older adults with or at risk of undernutrition compared to a standard supplement.
results_summary: The novel supplement group showed significantly greater improvements in walking performance over short (4m) and long (400m) distances compared to the standard supplement group, likely due to enhanced mitochondrial functioning. Both groups increased body mass, but fat mass increased more in the standard supplement group.
population_specificity: Older adults (>65 years) with or at risk of undernutrition (n=82).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and radiologic outcomes between two surgical techniques (bilateral decompression vs. unilateral decompression) in patients with claudication undergoing minimally invasive transforaminal lumbar interbody fusion (MIS-TLIF).
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain (VAS), disability (ODI), walking distance, or perioperative outcomes between the two surgical groups. Radiologic improvements in canal dimensions were observed in both groups, with no significant differences between them.
population_specificity: Patients with claudication who underwent MIS-TLIF.
study_duration: Follow-up assessments at 1, 3, 6, and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and feasibility of a physical activity-informed mealtime insulin bolus advisor that adjusts insulin doses based on step count data from walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in post-lunch hypoglycemia between standard therapy and the physical activity-informed method, suggesting that step count-adjusted insulin dosing is safe and feasible for mitigating glucose reduction after walking.
population_specificity: Fifteen adults with type 1 diabetes using continuous glucose monitors and insulin pumps.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine interest in a 3-month home-based walking regimen for advanced-stage lung cancer patients and evaluate its potential benefits on physical activity and quality of life.
results_summary: The intervention increased physical activity and showed borderline improvements in dyspnea and role functioning, with potential biomarker changes relevant to lung cancer biology. Step counts did not significantly change, but the intervention group showed greater PA improvement compared to usual care.
population_specificity: Stage III/IV non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients, predominantly women (75%), average age 65, mostly receiving treatment (85%).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention included accelerometer, in-person teaching, and text messages).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of intravenous ferric carboxymaltose (FCM) versus oral iron supplementation in improving exercise capacity (measured by the 6-minute walking test) and quality of life in heart failure patients with iron deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that FCM was more effective than oral iron in improving exercise capacity, with a trend toward better quality of life, suggesting FCM is the preferred treatment for iron deficiency in heart failure patients.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure and iron deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of resistance exercise, including its impact on walking performance, in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Resistance exercise significantly reduced the time of 50-foot walking in RA patients compared to the control group, indicating improved walking performance. However, no significant differences were observed in visual analog scale (VAS) scores or health assessment questionnaire (HAQ) scores.
population_specificity: Patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of yoga exercises combined with medial-thrust gait (YogaMT) on lower-extremity kinetics, pain, and function in patients with medial knee osteoarthritis, compared to knee-strengthening exercises and treadmill walking.
results_summary: The YogaMT group showed a significant reduction in knee adduction moment, while all groups improved in pain and function. The intervention may reduce medial knee load in the short term, but long-term outcomes require further study.
population_specificity: Patients with medial knee osteoarthritis (n=59).
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but follow-up was at 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of selective abobotulinumtoxin type A injections into the soleus versus gastrocnemius muscles on spastic foot drop in post-stroke patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in subjective and objective outcomes after 30 days, with no clinically relevant differences between the two muscle groups. Tendencies toward greater active range of motion improvement in the soleus group and passive range of motion improvement in the gastrocnemius group were observed.
population_specificity: 24 free-walking adult, botulinum toxin-naive patients with post-stroke hemiplegia.
effective_dosage: 800 MU aboBoNT/A in 4 mL saline, single injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of pulmonary rehabilitation (PR), which included walking, on exercise capacity and fatigue in subjects with pulmonary sarcoidosis.
results_summary: The PR program significantly improved VO2max, 6MWD, and quality of life scores (SGRQ and mMRC), with effects remaining stable at 6-month follow-up. Greater improvements were observed in subjects with more severe initial disease or specific pulmonary function parameters.
population_specificity: 52 subjects with stable pulmonary sarcoidosis.
effective_dosage: Twice-weekly 90-minute workouts (walking included in PR program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the clinical and molecular spectrum of Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome (WSS), including developmental milestones such as walking, in a diverse population.
results_summary: The study found that the median age at walking for individuals with WSS was 20 months, and identified common clinical features like developmental delay, hypertrichosis, and short stature. It also noted genotype-phenotype correlations, such as hypotonia being associated with loss-of-function variants.
population_specificity: 104 individuals with Wiedemann-Steiner syndrome from five continents, including White and Black Indigenous People of Color.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of n-3 EPA and DHA supplementation on fat-free mass and physical performance indicators, including walking, in the elderly.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 EPA + DHA supplementation significantly decreased the time of the Time Up and Go (TUG) test but showed no statistically significant effects on the 4-meter Walking Test or other physical performance indicators. Fat-free mass showed a non-significant improvement trend.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals (n = 2220 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify prognostic indicators of final ambulatory function in patients with subacute combined degeneration (SCD) from B12 deficiency.
results_summary: Greater ambulatory function at diagnosis was strongly associated with recovery of normal walking ability. Higher B12 replacement regimens correlated with improved ambulation, especially in patients initially unable to walk unsupported.
population_specificity: Patients ≥16 years of age with SCD from B12 deficiency.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate the Italian version of the Humpty-Dumpty Falls Scale (HDFS) and assess its predictive performance for pediatric falls, while also analyzing associations between clinical variables and falls.
results_summary: The Italian HDFS showed good validity and reliability but poor sensitivity and specificity. A modified version (HDFS-ita-M) performed better but still inadequately. Falls were most frequent in children aged 3-6 years, with motor/walking disorders, enuresis, and neurological conditions significantly associated with falls.
population_specificity: Hospitalized children aged 1-15 years.

study_goal: To determine the effect of preoperative nutrition and multimodal prehabilitation (including exercise like walking) on clinical and functional outcomes in lung cancer patients awaiting surgery.
results_summary: Multimodal prehabilitation (nutrition with exercise) improved functional walking capacity and pulmonary function preoperatively but did not affect postoperative outcomes. Nutrition-only interventions showed lower postoperative complication rates.
population_specificity: Lung cancer patients awaiting surgery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the impact of three training methods (aerobic exercise, gross motor abilities, and cognitive training) on mobility in healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found that all three interventions (aerobic, gross motor, and cognitive training) improved functional mobility in older adults, with significant improvements in TUG performance and usual gait speed.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults (mean age 69.28 ± 4.85 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of five pharmacotherapies (ACEIs, ARBs, BBs, MRAs, ARNI) used alone or in combination on cardiac reverse remodeling (CRR) and functional capacity, including 6-minute walking distance (6MWD), in heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF).
results_summary: The study found that dual-combination therapies (except ACEI+ARB) significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and NYHA class compared to placebo, with ARB+BB and ARNI+BB being the most effective. Functional capacity, measured by 6MWD, was included as a secondary outcome, but specific results for walking were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) (12,727 patients across 55 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intermittent pneumatic compression (IPC) in treating lower extremity wounds associated with lymphophlebitic disease, particularly in patients with poor functional status (walking less than 200m a day).
results_summary: The study found that IPC is beneficial for some patient cohorts with lymphophlebitic disease, especially those with poor ulcer healing factors like high BMI and limited walking. However, IPC is only part of a broader treatment algorithm that includes wound management, physical therapy, and lifestyle changes.
population_specificity: Patients with lower extremity venous stasis ulcers and lymphophlebitic disease, particularly those with high BMI (>33 kg/m²) and poor functional status (walking less than 200m a day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical and radiographic outcomes of the third-generation MICA technique for correcting hallux valgus deformity at a 2-year follow-up.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, walking/standing, and social interaction scores, as well as radiographic parameters, with low symptomatic recurrence rates.
population_specificity: 333 consecutive feet (292 analyzed) undergoing MICA surgery for hallux valgus deformity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility and safety of treadmill training for individuals with Lewy body dementia (LBD) or Huntington's disease (HD).
results_summary: Treadmill training was found feasible and safe for LBD and HD participants, but no significant changes in gait measures, TUG times, or Q-Motor measures were observed. Control participants showed improvements in some gait measures and foot tap frequency.
population_specificity: Individuals with Huntington's disease (HD), Lewy body dementia (LBD), and control individuals.
effective_dosage: 20-minute treadmill session with speed gradually increasing toward overground walking speed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore non-oncological outcomes, including physical function and gait, in sarcoma patients who underwent limb salvage surgery around the knee.
results_summary: The study found that patients often develop range of motion complications affecting gait patterns and limit participation in sports and leisure activities post-surgery. Rehabilitation should focus on walking ability and gait to prevent poor functional outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with sarcoma around the knee following limb salvage surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of acupoint autohemotherapy (AA) combined with western medicine versus western medicine alone in treating COPD.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that combined treatment improved clinical effectiveness, lung function (FEV1 and FVC), 6-minute walking distance, and COPD symptom scores (CAT). However, the conclusion was limited by the small number and poor quality of included RCTs.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the risks, benefits, and effects of non-slip socks in preventing hospital falls and their potential infection control risks.
results_summary: Most studies using non-slip socks to prevent hospital falls had negative or equivocal results, with low methodological quality and high risk of bias. Laboratory tests indicated non-slip socks were no safer than walking barefoot and could carry infection risks.
population_specificity: Hospital patients and laboratory settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of therapeutic ultrasound as a noninvasive treatment for improving walking ability in patients with intermittent claudication.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in 6-minute walking distance, Walking Impairment Questionnaire scores, and certain SF-36 domains after six weeks of ultrasound therapy, though ankle:brachial index showed only a nonsignificant trend toward improvement.
population_specificity: 10 subjects (5 male, 5 female, mean age 69.7 ± 10.3) with intermittent claudication.
effective_dosage: Pulsed ultrasound therapy at 250 kHz frequency for 30 minutes, three treatments per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether pre-admission community mobility influenced the effectiveness of a rehabilitation program on physical performance and activity in older adults recently discharged from the hospital.
results_summary: The rehabilitation program improved physical performance more in the intervention group compared to standard care, and pre-admission mobility appeared to influence the response to the counseling-based rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged ≥60 years recovering from lower limb or back injury, surgery, or other disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the feasibility of a nurse-coached walking intervention for informal caregivers of persons with dementia.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results regarding the effects of the walking intervention.
population_specificity: Informal caregivers of persons with dementia (5 male and 27 female participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of park-based interventions, including walking and exercise programs, in improving physical and mental health outcomes among adults.
results_summary: Person-based interventions, including park-based walking or exercise classes, showed statistically significant outcomes, while place-based interventions like park renovations increased park use and physical activity, though effects were more modest for programming. Hybrid methods combining place-based evaluations and cohort studies were suggested for optimizing health promotion strategies.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the effects of riociguat on pulmonary hypertension associated with idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, not Walking.
results_summary: The study found increased mortality in riociguat-treated patients, particularly those with combined pulmonary fibrosis and emphysema (CPFE), but no relationship between CPFE score, survival, and treatment assignment.
population_specificity: Patients with symptomatic pulmonary hypertension associated with idiopathic interstitial pneumonias.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a differentiated multidisciplinary educational program on functional outcomes, including walking ability, in patients undergoing total knee arthroplasty (TKA).
results_summary: The study found that the intervention group showed significantly better range of motion and walking ability (over 400 m) compared to the control group, with fewer patients requiring walking aids. Both groups improved in SF-36, WOMAC, VAS, and ROM, but the intervention group had superior outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing primary total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of aerobic exercise (walking) on neuroinflammation, neurodegeneration, and clinical measures in persons with multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: Aerobic exercise had minor effects on whole brain and grey matter atrophy but showed heterogeneous impacts on specific brain substructures (some increased, some decreased, some unchanged). It slightly improved walking speed and brain-derived neurotrophic factor levels but had no significant effect on other clinical, cognitive, or patient-reported outcomes.
population_specificity: Persons with multiple sclerosis (n=28, split into intervention and control groups).
effective_dosage: Twice weekly aerobic exercise (specific walking duration/intensity not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if mechanically assisted walking (treadmill or gait trainer) improves walking speed, distance, and participation compared to no/non-walking intervention or overground walking in ambulatory adults after stroke, and whether benefits persist beyond the intervention period.
results_summary: Treadmill walking increased walking speed by 0.13 m/s and distance by 46 m compared to no/non-walking intervention, with effects largely maintained post-intervention. It also showed similar or better effects on speed and distance compared to overground walking, though participation benefits were uncertain.
population_specificity: Ambulatory adults at any time after stroke.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effects of a novel high-PAS (paired associative stimulation) approach on walking and motor function in patients with incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI).
results_summary: The study found that high-PAS improved manual motor scores, functional hand tests, walking tests, and measures of functional independence in SCI patients, including tetraplegic and paraplegic individuals with varying injury severity, age, and time since injury.
population_specificity: 20 patients with incomplete SCI (tetraplegic and paraplegic, traumatic, and neurological).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of home-based exercise, including walking, on bone mineral density (BMD) in patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis (PD).
results_summary: The study found that home-based exercises, including walking, did not significantly improve BMD in PD patients but did improve physical function and activity, potentially reducing fall risk.
population_specificity: Stable outpatients undergoing peritoneal dialysis (median age 64-66 years, predominantly male).
effective_dosage: Not specified (home-based exercises included resistance, stretching, and aerobic activities like walking).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the prognostic role of potassium levels in patients with symptomatic chronic heart failure, including its association with cardiovascular events.
results_summary: Higher potassium levels (above 4.7 mmol/L) were independently associated with worse outcomes in chronic symptomatic heart failure patients, improving prognostic prediction when combined with the MAGGIC score and 6-minute walking test distance.
population_specificity: 178 patients with symptomatic chronic heart failure (mean age 51 ± 12.76 years, 39% female, 85% non-ischemic cardiomyopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine and compare the accuracy of different activity monitors in assessing intermittent outdoor walking in healthy and clinical populations.
results_summary: GPS receivers (GS and QS) and ActiGraph (AG) demonstrated high performance in detecting walking bouts and estimating speed/distance, with AG showing 100% bout detection in clinical populations. The StepWatch3 (SW) also performed well when using the study's algorithm.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and a clinical population with functional limitations during outdoor walking.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical effects of functional foot orthoses (FOs) with and without a lateral bar versus a control condition during comfortable and fast walking in individuals with cavus feet.
results_summary: During comfortable walking, both FOs decreased ankle dorsiflexion and increased knee extension angles compared to no FOs, with FOs featuring a lateral bar also reducing peroneus longus EMG amplitudes. At fast speeds, FOs decreased ankle dorsiflexion angles but showed no effects on EMG amplitudes or knee kinematics.
population_specificity: Fifteen individuals with cavus feet (age: 25.3 ± 5.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of powered versus unpowered prosthetic ankles on metabolic cost, walking speed, daily activity, and perceived mobility in individuals with transtibial amputations.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in metabolic cost, daily step count, walking speed, or perception of mobility between powered and unpowered prostheses. However, some participants reported improved ambulation and reduced frustration with the powered prosthesis, indicating subjective benefits despite lack of objective improvements.
population_specificity: Individuals with unilateral transtibial amputations.
study_duration: Two weeks of at-home prosthesis use.

study_goal: The researchers were investigating the diagnosis, surgical intervention, and outcomes of a rare case of nevus sebaceous in the genital region affecting walking difficulty.
results_summary: The study found that surgical removal of the bilateral labia minora lesions resolved the patient's walking difficulty, with no recurrence or other tumors observed after 40 months of follow-up. The researchers recommended surgical intervention during adolescence to mitigate malignant risks.
population_specificity: A 47-year-old woman with nevus sebaceous in the bilateral labia minora.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 5 days of in-hospital physiotherapy, including walking, could improve physical activity levels after cardiac valve surgery.
results_summary: The treatment group showed significantly greater handgrip strength and a trend toward improved timed up and go test performance compared to the control group, though the latter was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent cardiac valve surgery for confirmed cardiac valve disorders (n=34).
effective_dosage: Daily post-operative physiotherapy, including individualized mobilization, breathing exercises, and ambulation with or without a walking aid.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of ocrelizumab (OCR) on delaying the time to requiring a walking aid (EDSS score ≥6.0) in patients with relapsing multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: OCR significantly delayed the time to requiring a walking aid compared to interferon, with a 34% lower risk for ≥24-week confirmation and a 46% lower risk for ≥48-week confirmation over 6.5 years. Earlier initiation of OCR showed long-term benefits in reducing the need for walking aids.
population_specificity: Patients with relapsing multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: To compare the effects of two post-stroke walking rehabilitation interventions (ACC and SS) on walking function and prefrontal cortical activity.
results_summary: Both ACC and SS interventions improved preferred walking speed similarly, with no significant difference between groups. fNIRS data suggested ACC training may reduce prefrontal executive demands during walking.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic post-stroke hemiparesis and walking deficits.
effective_dosage: 36 sessions led by a physical therapist.
study_duration: 3 months (post-intervention assessment), with follow-up at 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether core stabilization exercises combined with an Asthma Education Program and breathing exercises improved respiratory muscle strength, physical activity level, functional exercise capacity, and dynamic balance in asthma patients.
results_summary: The Training Group showed significant improvements in inspiratory muscle strength, physical activity level, functional exercise capacity (measured by the six-minute walking test), and dynamic balance compared to the Control Group.
population_specificity: 40 asthmatic patients (mean age 52.25 ± 11.51 years).
effective_dosage: Breathing retraining exercises (2 times/week) and core stabilization exercises (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of combining brisk walking with computerized cognitive training (CCT) on executive functions and inter-network functional connectivity in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that improved executive function performance (measured by the Stroop Colour-Word Test and Flanker Test) was associated with decreased correlation between the default mode network (DMN) and the fronto-parietal network (FPN). The combination of brisk walking and CCT (Ex+CCT) was compared to CCT alone and a control group, but specific walking-related efficacy was not isolated in the abstract.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65-85 years.
effective_dosage: Brisk walking 3x/week for 1 hour (preceded CCT sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if there are differences in foot placement variables between the inner and outer legs during curve walking in a natural environment and whether these differences correlate with time or path curvature.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in stride and step length between inner and outer legs but identified significant differences in step width and relative foot angle. Correlations were found between curvature and step width, as well as time and relative foot angle.
population_specificity: 21 male participants aged 18-40 years.

study_goal: The researchers were examining the clinical presentation, diagnosis, and treatment of leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV), including the recommendation to avoid walking or standing as part of symptom management.
results_summary: The study found that LCV treatment includes symptom management strategies such as rest (avoiding walking or standing), corticosteroids, and other therapies, depending on whether the condition is skin-limited or systemic.
population_specificity: Patients with leukocytoclastic vasculitis (LCV).

study_goal: The researchers were attempting to determine whether statins cause muscle symptoms (e.g., pain, stiffness, weakness) in patients who previously reported such symptoms or considered discontinuing statin use.
results_summary: The study found no overall difference in muscle symptom scores between statin and placebo periods. A slight difference in withdrawals due to muscle symptoms suggests statins may contribute to symptoms in a small number of patients.
population_specificity: Patients who had discontinued or were considering discontinuing statin use due to perceived muscle symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, feasibility, and efficacy of a tablet-based supportive care platform, including walking, for managing symptoms in metastatic breast cancer patients.
results_summary: Patient satisfaction for walking was 83%, indicating high acceptability. The study found small nonsignificant improvements for fatigue and moderate reductions for sleep and distress, though these were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Seventeen patients with metastatic breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare methods of measuring dynamic hyperinflation (CPET, 6-MWT, MPT) in severe emphysema patients treated with endobronchial coils and assess changes post-treatment.
results_summary: No significant change in dynamic hyperinflation was observed after coil treatment. MPT showed strong association with CPET but may overestimate hyperinflation, while 6-MWT had only moderate association with CPET.
population_specificity: 29 patients with severe emphysema treated with endobronchial coils.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether inspiratory muscle training (IMT) improves walking capacity, strength, inspiratory muscle endurance, activities of daily living, and quality of life in poststroke patients.
results_summary: The study found that adding IMT to rehabilitation improved inspiratory muscle endurance but did not further enhance walking capacity (6MWT distance), maximal inspiratory pressure, activities of daily living, or quality of life compared to rehabilitation alone. Both groups showed similar improvements in walking capacity at six weeks.
population_specificity: Adult poststroke inpatients with inspiratory muscle weakness (mean age 53 ± 11 years).
study_duration: 6 weeks (with additional follow-up at 3 months post-intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare physical activity patterns, psychological wellbeing, and coping strategies of older adults with cognitive frailty in the WE-RISE trial (intervention vs. control) during the COVID-19 Movement Control Order.
results_summary: The WE-RISE intervention group showed significantly higher levels of walking activity, moderate activity, and total physical activity, along with greater functional independence and improved psychological wellbeing compared to the control group. Both groups relied on positive coping strategies, with the intervention group favoring religion and planning, while the control group used humor.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults aged 60+ with cognitive frailty in Klang Valley, Malaysia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and categorize conditions causing nail pain (onychalgia), including those exacerbated by activities like walking.
results_summary: The study identified four main groups of conditions causing nail pain (tumors, deformities, inflammatory/infectious diseases, and external/traumatic agents) and noted that walking could exacerbate pain in some cases.
population_specificity: Patients experiencing nail pain (onychalgia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if functional homogeneous laterality influenced postural tone symmetry during walking.
results_summary: The study found no significant influence of functional homogeneous laterality on postural tone, with subjects showing minimal deviation in walking patterns. Male and female subjects exhibited similar forward stepping distances but slight differences in lateral deviation.
population_specificity: 80 right-handed adults (52 males, 28 females) with a median age of 34.85 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a 4-week lifestyle program (WALK) in promoting physical activity and reducing sedentary behaviors among Korean American women.
results_summary: Both WALK-regular and WALK-plus groups increased vigorous activities and walking while decreasing sedentary behaviors on weekdays. WALK-plus, which included an online community component, showed significantly higher muscle-strengthening activity days compared to WALK-regular.
population_specificity: Korean American women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the relative effects (benefits and harms) of different internal fixation implants (smooth pins, screws, or fixed angle plates) for treating intracapsular hip fractures in older adults.
results_summary: The study found low-certainty evidence of little or no difference between screws and fixed angle plates in functional status, HRQoL, mortality at 12 months, or unplanned return to theatre, and between screws and pins in mortality at 12 months. Very low-certainty evidence suggested no significant differences in outcomes for smooth pins versus fixed angle plates.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 60-84 years, 73% women) with intracapsular hip fractures, 38% of which were undisplaced.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical implants, not a supplement).
study_duration: Follow-up periods varied, with outcomes measured at 4 months (early mortality) and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the HeartMan system, which includes decisional support for CHF management, on various health outcomes including exercise capacity (measured via a 6-minute walking test).
results_summary: The study found no significant intervention effects on exercise capacity (measured by the 6-minute walking test), but mental and sexual health and self-care behavior improved in the intervention group.
population_specificity: Ambulatory CHF patients in stable condition (77% male; mean age 63 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how influenza viruses interact with host cells and mucus, focusing on multivalent binding mechanisms and receptor dynamics.
results_summary: The study highlights that influenza viruses use weak multivalent interactions for superselective binding, receptor recruitment, and dynamic complex formation, facilitating molecular walking. It also discusses techniques to measure viral avidity and receptor specificity.
population_specificity: Not specified (focused on viral mechanisms, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional performance of three different total knee arthroplasty implant designs (CR DD, UC, and UCR) in osteoarthritic patients during walking and stair navigation.
results_summary: The UC implant provided the best post-operative function, closely followed by the UCR design, though both showed restricted sagittal range of motion during walking. The CR DD group exhibited the most significant improvement in sagittal range of motion during walking.
population_specificity: Twenty-four osteoarthritic patients and nine control participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of optimized multipoint pacing (MPP) versus optimized cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) on clinical, functional, and echocardiographic parameters in patients with dyssynchronous heart failure.
results_summary: Optimized MPP showed significant improvements over optimized CRT in 6-minute walking distance, NYHA class, and ventricular function, with more pronounced benefits in men and those with reduced LVEF.
population_specificity: 80 patients with dyssynchronous heart failure (77.5% male, 68.4 ± 10.1 years, 53.8% ischemic cardiomyopathy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of a community-based, volunteer-delivered weight management program (ActWELL) for women with a BMI >25 kg/m², initiated at breast screening clinics, in promoting weight loss and reducing breast cancer risk.
results_summary: The intervention group showed a mean weight loss of 2.5 kg compared to 1.2 kg in the comparison group, with a statistically significant adjusted mean difference of 1.3 kg. The odds of losing 5% body weight were 2.2 times higher in the intervention group, indicating clinically significant weight loss.
population_specificity: Women aged 50 to 70 years with a BMI >25 kg/m².
effective_dosage: Not specified (program included coaching sessions and support calls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of ankle-foot orthosis (AFO) and functional electrical stimulation (FES) in improving mobility and function for individuals with poststroke hemiplegia and decreased lower extremity motor control.
results_summary: Strong evidence supports that both AFO and FES improve gait speed, mobility, and dynamic balance, with moderate evidence for enhancing quality of life, walking endurance, and muscle activation. No overall superiority was found between AFO and FES, though AFO may lead to more compensatory effects while FES may have more therapeutic benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with poststroke hemiplegia and decreased lower extremity motor control.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current evidence on the use of fixed-time, self-paced walking tests (6MWT and 12MWT) as prognostic tools for patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).
results_summary: The study found that the 6MWT is a simple, cost-effective, and reliable measure of disease status and prognosis in IPF patients, though validated reference equations are needed. The role of the 12MWT remains understudied but may be useful for early-stage patients.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: To investigate the effects of non-paralytic dorsiflexion muscle strengthening exercise on functional abilities in chronic hemiplegic patients after stroke.
results_summary: Both experimental and control groups showed significant improvements in dorsiflexor muscle activities, balance abilities (TUG), and walking abilities (10MWT), with no significant intergroup differences.
population_specificity: Chronic hemiplegic patients after stroke (n=21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the clinical and imaging features of cerebrotendinous xanthomatosis (CTX) in a patient presenting with progressive difficulty in walking and tendon xanthomas.
results_summary: The study found that treatment with chenodeoxycholic acid led to a reduction in Achilles tendon xanthomas but no improvement in neurological impairment. The case highlights key diagnostic clues for CTX, including dentate nucleus abnormalities and spinal cord lesions.
population_specificity: A 40-year-old male with CTX and progressive walking difficulties.
effective_dosage: 250 mg chenodeoxycholic acid, 3 times per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the dose effects of exergaming volume and detraining duration on motor and cognitive function in office workers near retirement to reduce sedentariness and mobility limitations.
results_summary: Exergaming 2×/week produced the most significant improvements in mobility (19% increase in 6MWT distance) and selected cognitive outcomes, with effects retained over 8 weeks of detraining but less consistently after 16 weeks. A medium dose (2×/week) was most effective, while higher frequency (3×/week) showed diminishing returns.
population_specificity: Office workers aged 55-65 years with mild mobility limitations and intact cognition.
study_duration: 8 weeks of training followed by 8 and 16 weeks of detraining.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare muscle activation in the lower leg during walking with custom-made biomechanical footwear (BF), barefoot, and with a knee brace.
results_summary: Walking with BF resulted in significantly higher muscle activation in semitendinosus (ST), right lateral gastrocnemius (LG), and left tibialis anterior (TA) compared to barefoot or knee brace.
