The knee brace showed lower activation in right ST and LG, and left TA compared to barefoot.
population_specificity: Seventeen healthy working-aged individuals (mean age 29 years, SD 8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review preclinical and clinical data on the neuroprotective and symptomatic effects of 4-AP (fampridine) on walking disability in MS patients.
results_summary: The study found that 4-AP improves visual function, motor skills, and fatigue in MS patients, with its prolonged-release formulation (fampridine) approved for walking disability. The effects were attributed to Kv channel blockade, enhancing conduction in demyelinated axons, with potential additional neuroprotective properties.
population_specificity: Patients with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding nabiximols (Sativex) could improve muscle stiffness and daily activities like walking in people with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of the intervention on walking or other outcomes.
population_specificity: 21 people with multiple sclerosis (MS)

study_goal: To explore physiotherapists' views on the usability of feedback-based technologies, including virtual reality systems, handheld device apps, and wearable devices, in physical rehabilitation for improving mobility and physical activity.
results_summary: The study found that Fitbit, Fysiogaming, and Xbox Kinect were rated as acceptable for usability, with key factors including ease of setup, reliability, safety, and therapeutic benefits like customization and useful feedback. Usability was also influenced by context and support systems.
population_specificity: Aged care and neurological rehabilitation patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily acute intermittent hypoxia (AIH) combined with walking practice improves overground walking performance and intralimb motor coordination in individuals with chronic, incomplete spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: Participants showed improved walking speed and endurance after daily AIH + walking practice, with benefits persisting for weeks. The greatest improvements occurred in those using bilateral walking aids, but no significant changes in intralimb coordination were observed.
population_specificity: 11 individuals with chronic (>1 year), incomplete spinal cord injuries.
effective_dosage: 15 episodes of 10.0% O₂, 90 seconds each, daily for 5 consecutive days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare clinical and radiological outcomes of radical reduction surgery for developmental dysplasia of the hip (DDH) in children younger and older than 4 years of walking age.
results_summary: Children operated before age 4 had better clinical results (100% excellent/good) compared to those operated after (67%), and lower rates of avascular necrosis (19% vs. 33%). No significant difference was found in acetabular index improvement between age groups.
population_specificity: Children of walking age (mean 37.5±21 months) with DDH, divided into groups younger (27.9±4.9 months) and older (63.3±19.7 months) than 4 years.
study_duration: Mean follow-up was 29.9±19 months (younger group) and 19.6±5 months (older group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the characteristics, diagnosis, and conservative treatment of lumbar degenerative spondylolisthesis, including its impact on walking due to neurogenic claudication.
results_summary: The study found that lumbar degenerative spondylolisthesis often causes neurogenic claudication in 75% of patients, leading to lower limb pain during walking at variable distances. Conservative treatment, including physiotherapy, is the first-line therapy.
population_specificity: Elderly patients, predominantly women (5:1 ratio compared to men), with lumbar degenerative spondylolisthesis, most commonly affecting the L4-L5 segment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness, outcomes, and relapse rate of the Ponseti method for treating neglected clubfoot in patients older than one year.
results_summary: The Ponseti method corrected 87% of neglected clubfeet, with relapses occurring in 31% of cases, primarily in children under four years and those noncompliant with bracing. Residual equinus was treated with Achilles tendon sectioning in 83% of cases.
population_specificity: 303 patients (429 clubfeet) with neglected clubfoot, older than one year, from 15 centers across seven countries.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (treatment method involved casting and bracing, not a dosage).
study_duration: Median follow-up of 1.3 years (subset with 2-year follow-up for relapse analysis).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of an upper limb inhibition method combined with balance training on reducing associated reactions and improving walking function in chronic stroke patients.
results_summary: The shoulder elevation group showed significant improvement in elbow flexor contraction rates, walking speed (10MWT), and upper limb motor function (FMA-UE) compared to the back and control groups. No significant differences were found between the back and control groups.
population_specificity: Chronic stroke patients (n=60).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different rehabilitation interventions, including transcranial magnetic stimulation, functional electrical stimulation, and robotic-assisted treadmill training, on functional outcomes in individuals with spinal cord injury.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that transcranial magnetic stimulation improved walking speed and lower extremity function, functional electrical stimulation increased upper extremity independence, and robotic-assisted treadmill training enhanced lower extremity function compared to controls.
population_specificity: Individuals with spinal cord injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nonleisure-time physical activity guidance (NLTPAG), which emphasized walking for shopping and household activities, improved physical activity levels in patients after minor ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Physical activity levels significantly improved in the NLTPAG group (METs increased from 12.6 to 14.8, p = .035, r = .51), while no significant improvement was observed in the leisure-time physical activity guidance group. The results suggest NLTPAG may be effective for increasing physical activity in post-stroke patients.
population_specificity: Patients hospitalized for minor ischemic stroke (NIHSS ≤ 5).

study_goal: To determine the effect of walking as a physical activity intervention on blood pressure and heart rate.
results_summary: Walking reduces systolic blood pressure (SBP) and diastolic blood pressure (DBP) across all age groups and both sexes, with moderate-certainty evidence for SBP and mixed certainty for DBP and heart rate. Adverse events were rare, with knee injury being the most reported issue.
population_specificity: Participants aged 16 to 84 years, with approximately 1.5 times more females than males, from 22 countries.
effective_dosage: Average walking time per week was 153 minutes, with majority at moderate intensity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined aerobic, resistance, and inspiratory muscle training (ARIS) is superior to other exercise combinations in improving aerobic capacity, left ventricular dimensions, and functional outcomes in heart failure patients.
results_summary: The ARIS group showed trends for increased peakVO2, benefits in circulatory power, left ventricular end-systolic diameter, 6-minute walk test distance, quality of life, and program preference compared to other exercise combinations.
population_specificity: Heart failure patients (New York Heart Association II-III, left ventricular ejection fraction ≤35%, mean age 66.1 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether underwater treadmill gait training is more effective than overground gait training in improving gait and respiratory function in chronic severe hemiplegic stroke patients.
results_summary: Underwater treadmill gait training significantly improved step-time differences and maximal voluntary ventilation compared to overground training, suggesting better gait and respiratory outcomes for severe stroke patients. Both groups showed improvements, but the underwater treadmill group had superior results.
population_specificity: Adult patients with chronic severe hemiplegic stroke in a rehabilitation hospital setting.
effective_dosage: 30-minute sessions, two times per week for 12 weeks (alongside 60-minute neurodevelopmental treatment five times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of carbon-fiber spring (CAFO) and hinged ankle-foot orthoses (HAFO) in improving functionality and walking ability in children with diplegic cerebral palsy and crouch gait.
results_summary: The study found that CAFO produced more energy in stance and absorbed less energy compared to HAFO, but no statistically significant differences were found for other gait parameters. Preference for orthoses was evenly split among participants.
population_specificity: Ten children (5 males, 5 females) with diplegic cerebral palsy and crouch gait, aged 11 (4) years.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (orthotic devices, not a supplement).

study_goal: To determine the effects of a six-week Buddhist walking meditation program on exercise capacity, quality of life, and hemodynamic response in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: The six-week Buddhist walking meditation program did not significantly improve functional capacity, quality of life, or hemodynamic responses in heart failure patients, unlike the aerobic exercise program which showed significant improvement in functional capacity.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (mean age 65 years, New York Heart Association functional class II and III).
effective_dosage: At least three times a week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and feasibility of telehealth-delivered walking interventions for stroke survivors.
results_summary: The review found good adherence and satisfaction with no serious adverse events, but limited high-quality evidence of efficacy. Strategies like physiological monitoring and caregiver assistance were used to optimize safety and feasibility.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors, including those with cognitive impairment and some who walked independently.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinician-guided, pedometer-driven walking intervention for improving pain and disability levels in adults with chronic low back pain (CLBP) compared to standard education and advice.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in disability levels (ODI) between the walking group and the standard care group at any post-intervention time point. However, subgroup analyses suggested potential benefits for moderately disabled participants and those with low baseline step counts.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic low back pain (CLBP).
effective_dosage: Individually tailored daily step targets negotiated weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the impact of frailty, including slowed walking speed, on pancreas transplant candidates and recipients, drawing parallels from data on CKD, diabetes, and other solid organ transplant patients.
results_summary: The study highlights that frailty phenotypes, such as low walking speed, are prevalent in pancreas transplant candidates and recipients, and frailty negatively impacts transplant outcomes, including increased risks of prolonged hospitalization and delayed graft function.
population_specificity: Patients with diabetes or CKD, particularly pancreas transplant candidates and recipients, as well as other solid organ transplant patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of daily walking steps on glycated hemoglobin, BMI, and body composition in Japanese type 2 diabetes patients, while considering sedentary time.
results_summary: Higher daily walking steps (≥7,500) significantly reduced BMI and visceral fat accumulation independent of sedentary time, and reduced waist circumference in those with high sedentary time. No significant changes in glycated hemoglobin were observed across walking step categories.
population_specificity: Japanese type 2 diabetes patients (n=236) visiting an outpatient clinic.
effective_dosage: ≥7,500 daily walking steps (high step group) vs. <7,500 steps vs. non-step counter users.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of two lower limb constraint-induced movement therapy (CIMT) protocols—one based on task repetitions and the other on practice hours—for improving motor function after stroke.
results_summary: The study found that the group performing 600 daily repetitions (Group 1) showed significant improvements in motor impairment and other outcomes compared to the group practicing for 3 hours daily (Group 2). The results suggest that repetition-based CIMT is more effective for post-stroke rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Fifty-eight people with stroke.
effective_dosage: Group 1: 600 task repetitions daily; Group 2: 3 hours of task practice daily, both 5 times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of daily versus weekly feedback and contingent versus noncontingent incentives on increasing daily walking steps in insufficiently active adults with a BMI >25 kg/m².
results_summary: Daily feedback significantly increased daily steps compared to weekly feedback, while contingent incentives did not significantly outperform noncontingent incentives. A trend suggested that combining daily feedback with contingent incentives might be most effective.
population_specificity: Insufficiently active adults with a BMI >25 kg/m² (N = 57).
effective_dosage: Daily walking goal that adapted weekly (specific step count not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize the dose and concentration of PRP for knee osteoarthritis and evaluate its structural and physiological efficacy compared to hyaluronic acid.
results_summary: PRP with 10 billion platelets showed significant improvements in WOMAC and IKDC scores, increased pain-free walking distance, and reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6 and TNF-α) compared to hyaluronic acid at 1 year.
population_specificity: 150 patients with moderate knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: PRP (10 billion platelets) or hyaluronic acid (4 ml).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of increased physical activity (daily walking) in reducing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) incidence in high-risk pregnant women.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for walking alone, but it assessed walking as part of a factorial design to reduce GDM incidence, with primary and secondary endpoints including fasting glucose levels and maternal outcomes.
population_specificity: High-risk pregnant women aged ≥18 years and ≤16 weeks of gestational age in Vellore, South India, and The Gambia, West Africa.
effective_dosage: Daily walking (specific duration or intensity not detailed in the abstract).
study_duration: Minimum of 16 weeks, with follow-up until 32 weeks of gestation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of plantar pressure distribution in patients with hallux valgus during walking when using a toe separator versus a customized insole.
results_summary: The study found that after one month of use, the customized insole significantly reduced peak pressures and pressure-time integrals in the middle and lateral forefoot regions during walking compared to the toe separator.
population_specificity: Patients with hallux valgus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate evidence, good practices, and recommendations for rehabilitative treatment of disabilities associated with sarcopenia, focusing on exercise and nutritional supplementation.
results_summary: The study found that exercise and diet supplementation are key for rehabilitation in sarcopenia patients, improving autonomy, flexibility, balance, and coordination, which are essential for safe walking. High-grade recommendations support an adequate lifestyle as part of treatment.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the concurrent validity and reliability of the AMoR platform for step counting and measuring time spent sitting/lying in post-stroke individuals, as well as its accuracy at different walking speeds.
results_summary: The AMoR platform showed very high correlation and reliability for step counting and sitting/lying time, with mean absolute percentage errors below 4%. It also demonstrated high accuracy for step counting during the 10MWT.
population_specificity: Chronic post-stroke subjects (n=50)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of pedometer-supported walking and telemonitoring on pain, disability levels, and quality of life after lumbar disc hernia surgery.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significantly lower pain levels at the first and second months and lower disability levels at the second and third months compared to the control group. Additionally, quality of life subdimension scores (physical role difficulty, energy and vitality, mental health, social functionality, and pain) were higher in the third month for the intervention group.
population_specificity: Patients who had undergone lumbar microdiscectomy (67 participants, 33 in the intervention group and 34 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of virtual reality gait training (VRT) versus non-virtual reality gait training (non-VRT) on participation and walking ability in community-living individuals after stroke.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences between VRT and non-VRT in improving participation, walking ability, or other secondary outcomes. VRT was safe, well-tolerated, and positively rated by participants, but not more effective than non-VRT.
population_specificity: Community-living individuals between 2 weeks and 6 months post-stroke.
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 30-minute gait training over 6 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on gait automaticity, gait speed, and balance in patients with Parkinson disease (PD).
results_summary: The study found that RAGT improved single-task gait speed and balance but did not enhance gait automaticity or dual-task performance in PD patients. Cognitive dual-task interference increased post-treatment but returned to baseline at follow-up.
population_specificity: 11 patients with idiopathic Parkinson disease (mean age 66.46 years, disease duration 112.91 months).
effective_dosage: 12 sessions of 45-minute RAGT, 3 days a week for 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate morbidity, mortality, and functional outcomes (including ambulatory status) following periprosthetic femoral fractures (PFFs) after total hip arthroplasty.
results_summary: The study found high mortality rates (9.3% at 1 month, 22.3% at 1 year) and significant ambulatory impairment, with 57.9% of patients failing to regain their prefracture walking ability. Major systemic and local complications were also prevalent (23.4% and 12.1%, respectively).
population_specificity: Elderly patients (mean age 81) with periprosthetic femoral fractures after total hip arthroplasty.
study_duration: Retrospective study covering 2016-2017, with follow-up for at least 1 year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review how gait measurements in older adults influence frailty models and health-related outcomes across clinical, cognitive, physical, and nutritional domains.
results_summary: Gait was found to be a significant indicator of health and function in frail older adults, with various gait parameters predicting adverse outcomes in clinical, cognitive, and physical domains. The study highlighted heterogeneity in gait measurement protocols, limiting direct comparisons but supporting gait's role in understanding cognitive and motor decline.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those assessed for frailty.

study_goal: To determine whether high-intensity strength training reduces knee pain and knee joint compressive forces more than low-intensity strength training or attention control in patients with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: High-intensity strength training did not significantly reduce knee pain or knee joint compressive forces compared to low-intensity training or attention control at 18 months. Adverse events were reported but were mostly nonserious and unrelated to the study.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling adults aged 50+ with BMI 20-45, knee pain, and radiographic knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (strength training intensity varied but exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of paclitaxel-coated devices in treating lower limb peripheral artery disease to improve walking function and prevent restenosis.
results_summary: Paclitaxel-coated devices appear to reduce restenosis rates, but their impact on direct patient benefits and long-term mortality remains unclear due to trial heterogeneity, insufficient power, and lack of mechanistic explanation. Ongoing trials may provide clearer answers.
population_specificity: Patients with lower limb peripheral artery disease requiring endovascular revascularization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of bone marrow mononuclear stem cell transplantation in patients with dilated cardiomyopathy, focusing on outcomes including the six-minute walking test.
results_summary: The study found that bone marrow mononuclear stem cell therapy significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction and the six-minute walking test distance (28.53 meters more than controls), though the reduction in left ventricular end-diastolic diameter was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with non-ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy (mean age ~52-54 years).
effective_dosage: Varied by study (e.g., 1.94 × 10^6 CD34+ cells to 168 × 10^6 bone marrow mononuclear cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of mHealth-based exercise interventions on walking performance, functional status, and quality of life in patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).
results_summary: The study found that mHealth-based exercise interventions significantly improved pain-free walking, maximal walking, and 6-minute walk test distance in PAD patients, but no benefits were observed for walking speed, stair-climbing ability, or quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients with peripheral artery disease (PAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a home-based multimodal exercise program on muscle strength, balance, functioning, cognition, dual task performance, frailty, and physical activity level in older people with Alzheimer disease.
results_summary: The study expects improvements in the evaluated aspects (functioning, strength, balance, cognition, etc.) in the intervention group compared to the control group after 16 weeks of training. The protocol provides a theoretical basis for clinical interventions and health promotion measures for older people with Alzheimer disease.
population_specificity: Older people with mild and moderate Alzheimer disease (n=40).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the combined role of walking energetics and hip abductor strength on physical activity in older women with hip osteoarthritis.
results_summary: Greater energy used during walking was associated with lower self-reported physical activity, more sedentary time, and less light activity time. Lower hip abductor strength was also linked to reduced physical activity, and together these factors predicted 55.5% of the variance in self-reported physical activity.
population_specificity: 30 older women (61 ± 10 years) with moderately symptomatic hip osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the outcomes and functional impairments of patients with pulmonary hypertension (PH) in COPD versus idiopathic pulmonary arterial hypertension (IPAH), focusing on factors like 6-minute walking distance (6MWD) and survival rates.
results_summary: Patients with PH in COPD had worse 6MWD and functional class compared to IPAH patients, with lower survival rates. Improvements in 6MWD or functional class after PH treatment were associated with better outcomes in severe PH in COPD.
population_specificity: Patients with moderate or severe PH in COPD and patients with IPAH.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether Okada Purifying Therapy (OPT) combined with duloxetine improved walking ability in patients with Temporomandibular Disorders (TMDs) and Fibromyalgia (FM).
results_summary: The study found that both treatment groups improved over time, but only the interaction between treatment and time for walking ability showed a statistically significant difference (F=7.57, p=0.002). No further benefits from OPT were observed, though it may improve pharmacological tolerability.
population_specificity: Patients with TMDs and FM visiting the Department of Oral and Maxillofacial Sciences, Sapienza University of Rome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and benefits of dalfampridine versus placebo in improving walking ability and other functional outcomes in individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).
results_summary: Dalfampridine significantly improved walking ability (measured by the 12-item Multiple Sclerosis Walking Scale, timed 25-foot walk test, and 6-min walk test), finger dexterity (9-Hole Peg Test), and cognitive function (Symbol Digit Modalities Test) compared to placebo, but also had a higher incidence of side effects.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (1691 participants across 9 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the therapeutic effect of a postoperative hospital-based systemic rehabilitation protocol on ankle function in chronic ankle instability (CAI) patients.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in pain, symptoms, activities of daily living, sports activities, and quality of life (QOL) domains of the FAOS in the intervention group compared to the control group. Secondary outcomes, including ankle motor strength and spatiotemporal gait metrics, were also assessed.
population_specificity: Thirty-five patients who underwent a modified Broström procedure for chronic ankle instability (CAI).
effective_dosage: Fifty-minute sessions of hospital-based rehabilitation performed three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of general physical activity promoting interventions on functional and hospital outcomes in patients hospitalized over 48 hours.
results_summary: The study included four randomized controlled trials and performed meta-analyses for outcomes reported in two or more studies, using a random-effects model. The GRADE approach was used to assess the certainty of evidence, but specific results regarding walking's effects are not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients hospitalized for over 48 hours.

study_goal: To evaluate the efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided LR-PRP injections (single vs. double dose) for treating pes anserinus tendinobursitis (PATB).
results_summary: Both single and double-dose LR-PRP injections significantly improved pain (VAS), function (WOMAC), and walking capacity (6MWT) at 4 and 12 weeks post-treatment, with no statistical difference between the two dosing regimens. Likert scale results showed complete or significant relief in 78.4% of patients, though 6.7% reported worsened pain.
population_specificity: 60 patients with PATB (no significant demographic differences between groups).
effective_dosage: 2 mL LR-PRP (single dose or two doses one week apart).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of rivastigmine on gait in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease during single-task and dual-task walking trials.
results_summary: Rivastigmine significantly improved gait velocity during dual-task trials (counting backward and naming animals while walking) but not during single-task trials (walking at usual or fast pace). The improvement in dual-task gait was attributed to enhanced cognitive function rather than motor function.
population_specificity: 21 newly diagnosed patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of a breathing exercise on respiratory function and 6-minute walk distance in patients under hemodialysis.
results_summary: The breathing exercise improved pulmonary function parameters (forced vital capacity, forced expiratory volume in 1 second) but did not significantly affect 6-minute walk distance.
population_specificity: 52 patients under hemodialysis from a university teaching hospital in Iran.
effective_dosage: Not specified (breathing exercise program with incentive spirometry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of different initial doses of transdermal buprenorphine on pain relief, adverse effects, and quality of life in elderly osteoarthritis patients, including its impact on walking ability.
results_summary: The study found that transdermal buprenorphine reduced pain severity and improved quality of life, including walking ability, with no significant differences between dosage groups. Lower initial doses (8.75 μg/h and 17.5 μg/h) resulted in fewer adverse effects compared to the higher dose (35 μg/h).
population_specificity: Elderly patients (over 64 years old) with severe chronic pain due to osteoarthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing of postmeal walking to lower postprandial glucose (PPG) in overweight or obese young men.
results_summary: Walking initiated 20 minutes before PPG peak (20iP) significantly reduced PPG, plasma insulin, and C-peptide concentrations compared to sitting or walking at PPG peak (iP). The effects were more pronounced in men with higher BMI or glucose iAUC values during sitting.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese young men (age: 23.0 ± 4.3 y; BMI: 27.4 ± 2.8 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: Walking at 50% maximal oxygen consumption for 30 minutes.
study_duration: 240-minute trials per session, with sessions separated by 6-14 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the practicability, acceptability, and appropriateness of the Andago rehabilitation robot for training walking over-ground with bodyweight unloading in children with gait impairments.
results_summary: The Andago was found to be practical and well-accepted, with no technical difficulties and prevention of falls. Stride-to-stride variability was higher in Andago compared to treadmill walking, and muscle activity was minimally affected by bodyweight unloading levels.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with gait impairments undergoing neurorehabilitation.
effective_dosage: Three levels of bodyweight unloading (median: 20%, 35%, and 50% of bodyweight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the impact of osteoarthritis (OA) on joint function and activity limitation, particularly focusing on hip and knee OA, and to evaluate management strategies, including walking as a valued activity.
results_summary: The study found that OA leads to joint dysfunction, pain, and loss of valued activities like walking. Management strategies, including exercise (such as walking), weight loss, and education, are effective, with walking being a key activity for maintaining physical function.
population_specificity: Individuals with hip and knee osteoarthritis, particularly adults, including those over 75 years, females, and those with obesity or joint injuries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prenatal repair of myelomeningocele improved physical functioning, including walking skills, compared to postnatal repair in children aged 5 to 10 years.
results_summary: Children with prenatal repair showed better self-care skills, functional mobility, and walking abilities, including faster walking speeds and improved gait quality, compared to those with postnatal repair. They were also more likely to be community ambulators and had better motor function relative to their anatomic lesion level.
population_specificity: Children aged 5 to 10 years with myelomeningocele who underwent either prenatal or postnatal repair.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (surgical intervention, not a supplement).
study_duration: Follow-up assessments were conducted from ages 5 to 10 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility and clinical impact of the Atrial Flow Regulator (AFR) device in heart failure patients, not specifically Walking.
results_summary: The study found that AFR implantation was feasible, with device patency maintained at 3 and 12 months, and some patients showed improvements in functional class, walking distance, and quality of life. No shunt occlusion, stroke, or new right heart failure was observed.
population_specificity: Symptomatic heart failure patients with reduced or preserved ejection fraction and elevated pulmonary capillary wedge pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a Fitbit program to improve physical activity (walking) in endometrial cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study found a 22% increase in average steps at 6 months, but this returned to baseline by 9 months. The telephone intervention showed temporary improvements in activity levels, with the greatest impact on patients with high baseline walking frequency and low baseline step count.
population_specificity: Endometrial cancer survivors (stage IA-IIIA, ≥3 months post-treatment).
study_duration: 9 months (intervention communication every 2 weeks for 2 months, then once during months 4 and 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a single session of walking exercise reduces arterial stiffness in symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD) patients.
results_summary: Walking exercise did not significantly alter arterial stiffness compared to control or other exercise sessions, with no difference found between walking, combined exercise, and resting conditions. The study found that resistance exercise, not walking, acutely reduced arterial stiffness in these patients.
population_specificity: Twelve patients with symptomatic peripheral artery disease (PAD).
effective_dosage: 10 bouts of 2-minute walking at the speed corresponding to the onset of claudication pain, with 2-minute intervals between sets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of empagliflozin on pulmonary artery pressures and other hemodynamic measures in patients with heart failure, regardless of ejection fraction or diabetes status.
results_summary: Empagliflozin significantly reduced pulmonary artery diastolic pressure (PADP) starting at week 1, with effects amplifying over time, and appeared independent of loop diuretic management. Secondary outcomes included health status, natriuretic peptides, and 6-minute walking distance, though specific walking-related results were not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (mean age 66, 63% male, 52% with type 2 diabetes, 54% NYHA class III/IV, mean ejection fraction 44%) and previously implanted pulmonary artery pressure sensors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of unsupervised Nordic walking and regular walking on maintaining improvements in overweight/obese adults after a supervised training period.
results_summary: Unsupervised training did not further improve performance, but participants, especially in the Nordic walking group, maintained some benefits from the supervised phase. Instructor-led training may enhance adherence and health benefits.
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults (aged 66 ± 7-8 years, BMI 32-34 ± 5).
study_duration: 6 months unsupervised following 6 months supervised training (total 12 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess amputation and mortality rates, as well as risk factors and outcomes (including return to walking) in patients with Charcot neuroarthropathy following reconstruction.
results_summary: The study found that 15.2% of patients underwent limb amputation post-reconstruction, and 14.6% died. Patients with ankle or subtalar joint reconstruction were 70% less likely to return to walking compared to medial column reconstruction.
population_specificity: Patients with Charcot neuroarthropathy (n=151) over a 5-year period.
study_duration: Follow-up at 30 days, 1 year, and 3 years post-reconstruction.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if the 6-minute walk test (6MWT) could predict clinical decompensation in patients with cirrhosis after 1 year of follow-up.
results_summary: The study found that a walking distance ≤ 401.8 m during the 6MWT predicted clinical decompensation with 64% sensitivity and 82% specificity. Patients walking < 401.8 m had a 30% decompensation-free outcome rate compared to 75% for those walking > 401.8 m (p<0.001).
population_specificity: Patients with compensated cirrhosis of various etiologies, mean age 56.3±10.5 years, 65% male, 65.4% Child-Pugh class A.
effective_dosage: Not applicable (6MWT is a performance test, not a dosage).

study_goal: The study does not evaluate Walking; it focuses on the efficacy and mechanisms of Bufei Yishen formula (BYF) for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
results_summary: The study does not report any findings related to Walking.
population_specificity: Patients with COPD and COPD rat models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate correlations between socio-demographic/clinical factors and the use of prostheses for indoor/outdoor walking (community ambulation) in lower limb amputation (LLA) subjects.
results_summary: The study found that prosthesis use and trans-tibial amputation level were significant predictors of improved community ambulation. Factors like gender, work activity, and time since amputation also influenced outcomes, while age negatively correlated with recovery.
population_specificity: 302 subjects with lower limb amputation who received similar rehabilitative treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the management of acute limb ischemia caused by arterial vasospasm due to ergotamine overdose in combination with HIV protease inhibitors.
results_summary: The study found that combining medical vasodilator therapy with interventional procedures (such as transluminal balloon angioplasty) effectively restored arterial blood flow and rescued lower limbs in severe arterial vasospasm cases. The case demonstrated the ineffectiveness of first-line vasodilator therapy alone and highlighted the necessity of interventional approaches.
population_specificity: A 33-year-old woman with orthostatic hypotension taking dihydroergotamine and prescribed HIV post-exposure prophylaxis (lopinavir and ritonavir).
interactions: Interaction between dihydroergotamine and HIV protease inhibitors (lopinavir and ritonavir) leading to ergotism and arterial vasospasm.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the real-world long-term efficacy and safety of alglucosidase alfa in adult Pompe disease patients, including its impact on walking capability (6MWT).
results_summary: The study observed an initial improvement in walking capability (6MWT) followed by a secondary decline after long-term enzyme replacement therapy (ERT). The efficacy of ERT diminished over time, with a sustained decline in multiple outcome measures, including walking.
population_specificity: Adult Pompe disease patients from Spain, Taiwan, Italy, and Germany.
study_duration: Mean follow-up of 7.03 years (±2.98), with ERT administered for at least 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of robot-assisted gait training (RAGT) on balance and gait outcomes in people with multiple sclerosis (PwMS).
results_summary: RAGT, primarily using exoskeletons, improved balance and gait outcomes in PwMS, achieving clinically meaningful differences in the Berg Balance Scale, six-minute walking test, and gait speed. The training was often combined with multimodal rehabilitation or standard physical therapy.
population_specificity: People with multiple sclerosis (PwMS), with varying levels of disability.
effective_dosage: Exoskeleton training: 6-40 sessions, 2-5 per week; end-effector training: 12 sessions, 2-3 per week.
study_duration: Varied by study, ranging from 6 to 40 sessions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the available literature on drug pharmacodynamics in infants with pulmonary hypertension (PH), including the use of medications like iNO and sildenafil.
results_summary: The study found that mortality in infants with PH has decreased significantly, with iNO and sildenafil being widely used, though pharmacodynamic data in children are lacking compared to adults.
population_specificity: Infants with pulmonary hypertension (PH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the existing scientific literature on exercise training (including walking) in patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) and identify gaps for future research.
results_summary: The study found that exercise training, including walking, significantly improved 6-minute walking distance, peak aerobic capacity, reduced dyspnea, and enhanced quality of life in IPF patients, though long-term effects and predictors of improvement require further exploration.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the functional outcomes of passive, adaptive, and active prosthetic knees in individuals with transfemoral amputation.
results_summary: Adaptive control improved comfortable TUG time and physical function, while active control increased TUG, ramp times, and balance confidence but restricted mobility in middle-age or older users.
population_specificity: 12 participants with unilateral transfemoral amputation (mean age = 58 years).
effective_dosage: Not applicable (prosthetic knee conditions, not a supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the relationship between perceived fatigability and metabolic measures, including oxygen consumption and the energy cost of walking, in older women.
results_summary: Perceived fatigability was not directly linked to metabolic measures but was associated with higher oxygen cost of walking, lower physical activity, shorter walking distance, and greater performance fatigability.
population_specificity: Forty-eight community-dwelling older women from senior centers in Natal, Brazil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of walking impairment in multiple sclerosis (MS) and the need for patient education, assessments, and management strategies.
results_summary: The study found that walking impairment occurs early in MS and significantly affects socioeconomic outcomes. It highlighted the importance of combining patient-reported and objective measures to monitor changes and facilitate discussions on management strategies.
population_specificity: Individuals with multiple sclerosis (MS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of instrumented footwear for gait analysis and retraining outside clinical settings.
results_summary: The study suggests that instrumented footwear can enable out-of-lab gait analysis and serve as a retraining tool using acoustic or vibrotactile stimuli, addressing the limitations of traditional gait laboratories.
population_specificity: Patients requiring gait analysis or retraining (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate a self-reported Walking Speed Questionnaire (WSQ) as an effective tool for assessing baseline gait speed in older adults when conventional measurement is contraindicated.
results_summary: The WSQ significantly predicted true gait speed (r = 0.696, ρ = 0.717) and all four questions independently correlated with measured gait speed (P < 0.001). The tool enables gait screening in settings where direct testing is impractical, such as trauma cases.
population_specificity: Ambulating individuals aged 60-95 (mean age 73.2 ± 8.1 years, 86.1% female, n = 101).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dalfampridine ER 5 and 10 mg BID on walking distance in people with multiple sclerosis (MS) using the 6-minute walk test and patient-reported outcomes.
results_summary: Dalfampridine ER 10 mg BID significantly improved walking distance (37.3% vs 12.2% placebo) and walking speed (45.1% vs 14.3% placebo) compared to placebo, with no significant efficacy observed for the 5 mg dose. Improvement in patient-reported walking impact (MSWS-12) correlated with ≥20% increase in walking distance.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-70 with multiple sclerosis (N = 153 with 6MW data).

study_goal: To investigate the effect of 8-week whole body vibration training on gait performance and lower extremity function in stroke patients with knee hyperextension.
results_summary: The intervention group showed significant reductions in knee hyperextension times and improvements in walking function (10-meter walk test) and lower limb function (Fugl-Meyer assessment) compared to the control group. All three tests demonstrated statistically significant improvements post-training in both groups.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with knee hyperextension (n=30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of inspiratory muscle training and calisthenics-and-breathing exercises combined with physical training on respiratory muscle strength, endurance, thoracoabdominal mobility, exercise capacity, and dyspnea in COPD patients.
results_summary: Both interventions improved respiratory muscle strength, endurance, thoracoabdominal mobility, and walking distance, while reducing dyspnea. Inspiratory muscle training was more effective in increasing respiratory muscle strength and endurance, particularly in subjects with respiratory muscle weakness.
population_specificity: 25 subjects with COPD (13 in the inspiratory muscle training group, 12 in the calisthenics-and-breathing exercises group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate maximal oxygen consumption, walking efficiency, and maximal strength in substance use disorder (SUD) patients compared to a reference group.
results_summary: SUD patients exhibited significantly lower maximal oxygen consumption (15% lower in men, 25% in women), 13% reduced walking efficiency, and 30-33% lower maximal strength compared to healthy controls. These impairments suggest higher risks of cardiovascular and lifestyle-related diseases.
population_specificity: 44 SUD patients in residential treatment (31 men, 13 women) compared to an age- and sex-matched reference group.
